headline.main: GRITS, CORN BREAD AND OTHER HAUTE CUISINE RECIPES

docs.lead_paragraph: THE following new American dishes offered at three Manhattan restaurants have been adapted here for home cooking. In the pheasant recipe, Lawrence Forgione of the River Cafe uses wild mushrooms instead of cultivated ones, uses a green called lamb's quarters instead of spinach and adds eight wild garlic mustard leaves to the corn bread mixture. Unfortunately, getting these items is not easy, even for those who live in the country, so appropriate substitutes are listed. When crayfish and catfish are not available, the Hubert's recipe can be made with shrimp and fillets of gray sole.

byline.contributor: Adam Wu contributed research from Chengdu, China.

docs.abstract: Chefs of traditional Sichuanese cooking in Chengdu, China, say cuisine has been overcommercialized and degraded due to its rising popularity and rapid global growth; chefs have formed society to restore cuisine’s time-honored ways, and Chinese government has plans to create Michelinlike rating system for Sichuanese restaurants at home and abroad; recipe for San Hua Kao Ji, Three-Flower Roast Chicken, offered.
docs.lead_paragraph: In Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, the region’s famed cuisine is more popular than ever. But traditionalists worry it’s drowning in spice.
docs.snippet: In Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, the region’s famed cuisine is more popular than ever. But traditionalists worry it’s drowning in spice....

headline.print_headline: Jewish Leader Asks Michelin to Taste Israeli Cuisine
headline.main: Jewish Leader Asks Michelin to Taste Israeli Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: The leader of an umbrella organization representing world Jewry has asked the Michelin travel guide company to evaluate Israeli restaurants with its famous rating system, implying that the decision to omit the country may be political.

headline.main: New English Cuisine on the Road to Mandalay

docs.abstract: R W Apple Jr surveys London restauran
docs.lead_paragraph: AT Nahm, you are surrounded by blond wood, gold leaf and slightly too many slightly too skinny women. You eat authentic Thai dishes with names like miang som oo and hoi shenn pat khaa orn, some of them stunningly spicy, most of them challenging to pedestrian palates. You drink the best of wines from California, New Zealand, Australia and South Africa, or Thai beer. To get to Hakkasan, which is in what used to be a basement parking garage, you grope your way down a murky alley near the British Museum and look for a burly, black-clad doorman. There is no sign. Once inside, you find yourself in a series of rooms with cobalt-blue walls, a space that one London critic described as achingly cool, with people younger and hipper than you. At lunch, you eat dim sum, at dinner a robust range of Beijing-, Taipei- and Shanghai-inspired food, served by waitresses clad in cheongsams.
